topics.topic_html:
The `<p>` tag in HTML is used to define a paragraph. It groups text or other inline elements into a block-level structure, typically adding some space above and below the content, creating separation from other elements on the page. This tag helps organize content in a readable way.

Hereâ€™s a simple example of how it works:

```html
<p>This is a paragraph of text. It will be displayed with some space above and below it.</p>
<p>This is another paragraph of text, which will be similarly spaced.</p>
```

Each `<p>` element creates a new paragraph, and the browser will automatically insert some margin to visually separate it from other content. 

The `<p>` tag can contain text, inline elements (like `<a>`, `<strong>`, or `<em>`), but not block-level elements (like `<div>` or `<h1>`).
